Missing Data

Adrian Waddell

2018-10-31

missing-data.Rmd

This document summarizes our decisions regarding working with missing data in tern.

library(tern)

col_by

Missing values in factor variables assigned to the col_by agruments will cause an error.

t_summary(1:3, col_by = factor(c(NA, "a", "b")))
#> Error in stop_if_has_na(col_by): col_by does currently not support any NAs

You can use the addNA function to convert the NAs to a new level:

t_summary(1:3, col_by = addNA(factor(c(NA, "a", "b"))))
#>                    a             b             NA  
#>                  (N=1)         (N=1)         (N=1) 
#> ---------------------------------------------------
#> n                  1             1             1   
#> Mean (SD)        2 (NA)        3 (NA)        1 (NA)
#> Median             2             3             1   
#> Min - Max        2 - 2         3 - 3         1 - 1

There are more ways to recode NAs in factor variables as described in this stackoverflow thread.

t_summary.factor

When summarizing factor variables the missing values do not get listed by default.

t_summary(x = factor(c(letters[1:5], NA)), col_by = factor(rep(c("I", "II"), 3)))
#>              I                 II    
#>            (N=3)             (N=3)   
#> -------------------------------------
#> n            3                 2     
#> a        1 (33.33%)          0 (0%)  
#> b          0 (0%)           1 (50%)  
#> c        1 (33.33%)          0 (0%)  
#> d          0 (0%)           1 (50%)  
#> e        1 (33.33%)          0 (0%)

In order to display the missing values one can use the useNA argument similar as in table to convert missing values in factor variables to "<NA>":

t_summary(x = factor(c(letters[1:5], NA)), col_by = factor(rep(c("I", "II"), 3)), useNA = "ifany")
#>                 I                 II    
#>               (N=3)             (N=3)   
#> ----------------------------------------
#> n               3                 2     
#> a           1 (33.33%)          0 (0%)  
#> b             0 (0%)           1 (50%)  
#> c           1 (33.33%)          0 (0%)  
#> d             0 (0%)           1 (50%)  
#> e           1 (33.33%)          0 (0%)  
#> <NA>            0                 1
